entry.title: Move core logic of no-index to fetch-reindex (#322)
entry.content:
commit 275e3a69796dbfdb4816871d097897236ade09fa parent 7dc9f16082ce3023f45a9bd55465a90ceaf9fea7 Author: juliannadeau-stripe <96543276+juliannadeau-stripe@users.noreply.github.com> Date: Tue 22 Feb 2022 19:23:55 -0500
Move core logic of no-index to fetch-reindex (#322)
* Move core logic of no-index to fetch-reindex
The original PR implemted the logic in github-reindex not realizing that the fetching of the repos was tightly coupled to fetch-reindex. This means that, with the old implementation, you could run the config generation but nothing would actually update. You would just have HEAD but the repos would still be outdated.
Ideally we could de-couple github operations from indexing operations and independently fetch/index, but saving a full refactor the easiest solution is to pass the flag into fetch-reindex and exit after fetching repos
* Format bool as string
* conditionally append --no-index flag
Co-authored-by: Alex Suraci <vito@stripe.com>

entry.title: Concurrent reindexer GitHub requests (#315)
entry.content:
commit 80aed2ec2fb1ab330c4d6cee84d10ebb586f2726 parent e96c2abda40847031925ef5b362e66791128c6bd Author: Rodrigo Silva Mendoza <xvandish@users.noreply.github.com> Date: Thu 23 Dec 2021 17:44:22 -0700
Concurrent reindexer GitHub requests (#315)
* working implementation of concurrent github repository fetches
* add configurable number of repo workers to fetch-reindex
* log out remaining rate
* use cancel context for concurrent requests
* remove timeTrack, spacing change and debug log
* manually remove use of flag that used to exist in feature branch, but no longer does in main
Co-authored-by: Rodrigo Silva Mendoza <rsilva@psi.edu>

entry.title: allow github-live-reindex to generate config file for file viewer (#310)
entry.content:
commit 74f249946800bda2c6bc9e53813c4163355db7ea parent f042ef33826cf91f14d796f3c040a006be101886 Author: Rodrigo Silva Mendoza <xvandish@users.noreply.github.com> Date: Tue 12 Oct 2021 19:38:18 -0700
allow github-live-reindex to generate config file for file viewer (#310)
The switch in 8c639ff5f1b7e3916ed1c480eeab6bc50c4f8c73 to use the protobuf config files made it so that the config file written by github-live-reindex stored repoitories under `repos` instead of `repositories` as google/protobuf does not support custom json tags in structs. Did the easy thing and normalized every instance of IndexConfig/IndexSpec to use `repositories`, instead of `repos` in some places and `repositories` in others.
also add file view/repository browser section to readme and add graceful failure handling if url_pattern is not present for repos in config file

entry.content:
commit 1358b0699d382e02012d6a89003790edf552c092 parent 07eec4569039116a2974dc3dac160040219367b2 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 10 Oct 2020 16:30:08 -0700
Merge pull request #281 from staktrace/newline
Avoid messy stderr output in some cases

entry.title: Avoid messy stderr output in some cases
entry.content:
commit 5fe3e49def4d4ba987f7248f70b96ba3b2860856 parent 07eec4569039116a2974dc3dac160040219367b2 Author: Kartikaya Gupta <kats@trevize.staktrace.com> Date: Sat 10 Oct 2020 03:43:45 -0400
Avoid messy stderr output in some cases
If the repo being indexed has files that are too large, a WARN line is emitted between the "walking HEAD..." and "done" outputs. This results in messy stderr that looks like this:
walking HEAD... WARN: file is too big to be indexed WARN: file2 is too big to be indexed done
Apart from looking messy, this makes it harder to autodetect warnings with grep. It seems better to insert a newline after the "walking HEAD..." output, which also makes it consistent with the other branch of code immediately above.

entry.title: Merge pull request #278 from livegrep/fix-re2-name
entry.content:
commit 7b3cccb9c9e6201fb309f72fc4d580807e65bd12 parent cfd4c6cf7be6a6860407d0658f582936fa5558b5 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 30 Aug 2020 19:29:36 -0700
Merge pull request #278 from livegrep/fix-re2-name
Update the name of the RE2 dependency

entry.title: Update the name of the RE2 dependency
entry.content:
commit ea95e52a4cf0ff35f169a2ca8edfb18768a02d47 parent cfd4c6cf7be6a6860407d0658f582936fa5558b5 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 30 Aug 2020 19:06:59 -0700
Update the name of the RE2 dependency
GRPC also depends on RE2, by the `com_github_google_re2` name. The fact that we were using a different name resulted in GRPC pulling in a second copy. This used to mostly work fine because they were ABI-compatible, at least in the pieces we use. However, RE2 recently updated the layout of a core struct in 572d6abf7f227053a4f8b83381fc4378714a2552, which meant that we ended up seeing one version of the headers and linking against a different version of the objects, which was a no good bad time.
IMO this is arguably a bug in GRPC's bazel build -- it should not be leaking those headers -- but this fix is correct in any case.

entry.title: Merge pull request #272 from christopherb-stripe/constant-revision-lookup
entry.content:
commit 593b4dd32fe75a2eb5f36822fcedb56075bfe800 parent 464d51c9c4e0b985c6e92364f7e74e2e72d8d397 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 26 Jul 2020 14:05:19 -0500
Merge pull request #272 from christopherb-stripe/constant-revision-lookup
Improve commit SHA lookup performance

entry.title: Improve commit SHA lookup performance
entry.content:
commit e22b909ef86bd61b5155ac34b13b86984cd5e4e2 parent 464d51c9c4e0b985c6e92364f7e74e2e72d8d397 Author: Christopher Brown <christopherb@stripe.com> Date: Fri 24 Jul 2020 16:17:34 -0700
Improve commit SHA lookup performance
We were seeing high latencies (~4s) when viewing files inside a repository with a lot of branches (~14000). This was tracked down to this git show invocation.
As far as I can see, git show is built on top of git log. The git log command iterates over every branch head to gather the information it needs to render the standard git log output even if this information is ultimately discarded before being displayed. The git rev-parse command looks up just the information we need in a constant number of disk accesses.
Before:
$ time git -C $REPO show --quiet --format="%H" HEAD ac00907bc674a675bc0de94ceb467cb884e82795
real 0m4.711s user 0m4.076s sys 0m0.256s
After:
$ time git -C $REPO rev-parse HEAD ac00907bc674a675bc0de94ceb467cb884e82795
real 0m0.003s user 0m0.004s sys 0m0.000s

entry.title: Add a -reuseport option
entry.content:
commit 6cfc6b7c642c33e32189eb414ad91b43b4f55207 parent 3bcd52d4531e61505117aa251265fc93de26d7b1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 19 Apr 2020 22:15:53 -0700
Add a -reuseport option
This allows disabling SO_REUSEPORT, so that subsequent concurrent server instances running on the same port will exit with an error, instead of load-balancing with the existing one.
Fixes #262

entry.content:
commit 3c4c7383a6702162c26280e8aa2a4ce63cbe1716 parent dc9f4d33a56b857482366bbd20acff9077ccdffe Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Mon 6 May 2019 15:23:28 -0700
Merge pull request #228 from benjaminp/fcb-undef
Avoid undefined behavior in file_contents_builder::build.

entry.title: Avoid undefined behavior in file_contents_builder::build.
entry.content:
commit 7e838c435713f621092e08cb1349c170c5c5a08e parent dc9f4d33a56b857482366bbd20acff9077ccdffe Author: Benjamin Peterson <benjamin@python.org> Date: Mon 6 May 2019 15:13:50 -0700
Avoid undefined behavior in file_contents_builder::build.
file_contents_builder::build was unconditionally constructing a file_contents object over the result of the allocator. If the allocator returned nullptr, undefined behavior happened. Move the nullptr check earlier to fix this.

entry.title: Add a flag to include submodules when walking the tree.
entry.content:
commit f7ad298837a4089897740d3d91c8998c68454ccf parent b4a9d6cf1ce6d39d71abc70f7a636ca953f43fe3 Author: Kartikaya Gupta <kats@trevize.staktrace.com> Date: Sun 3 Mar 2019 10:53:24 -0500
Add a flag to include submodules when walking the tree.
The flag, when set to true, will treat submodules as though they are just regular files inside the parent repo. The submodule is indexed at the revision that the parent repo points to.
Fixes livegrep/livegrep#216

entry.title: Merge pull request #215 from lopopolo-stripe/range-anchor-github-syntax
entry.content:
commit 5e3b314f44dd08ba5fe2f9fe213a185cd3f8fe84 parent 541e7821f1fbd19b0899cf1d9eb1b7a16c1b534a Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 20 Feb 2019 10:25:24 -0800
Merge pull request #215 from lopopolo-stripe/range-anchor-github-syntax
Allow GitHub-style line range anchors

entry.title: Allow GitHub-style line range anchors
entry.content:
commit a80b5505f3b593929edf378eed7032ed61012139 parent 541e7821f1fbd19b0899cf1d9eb1b7a16c1b534a Author: Ryan Lopopolo <lopopolo@stripe.com> Date: Wed 20 Feb 2019 10:11:28 -0800
Allow GitHub-style line range anchors
When linking to a range in GitHub, the syntax is #L43-L70. With livegrep, the syntax is #L43-70. This inconsistency causes me to make a lot of mistakes.
This patch makes the fileview frontend accept both anchor styles for linking to line ranges.

entry.title: Remove the indexing timers.
entry.content:
commit ea24af4f6be9aff095c5d399809eac7830e9cb8d parent 2bdf2509ea64d6f5e2d1365b4701f26a88e14632 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 27 Jan 2019 16:42:51 +0000
Remove the indexing timers.
Especially one machines where gettimeofday is a real syscall, these were adding pretty significant overhead to the indexer. We could try to keep them selectively, but I'm just going to use other tools to analyze performance, instead.

entry.content:
commit 94f64cd24c41250d641d9f36dbaf0792e0a52dba parent 953733bae75dbf1a9a360bb49d6ea04a6ac9a167 Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 11 Oct 2018 12:22:30 -0400

entry.title: Prevent | from breaking tags-based searches
entry.content:
commit fb0cdcae12ccc8802ba70154ffb36297a127e1b0 parent 8d2a746de26da9e4e7c0ba50a405dc3f066681af Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 11 Oct 2018 11:33:15 -0400
Prevent | from breaking tags-based searches
An interior | inside either the main pattern or the file path pattern would cause the tags-based search to match many lines it should not, since the subordinate patterns were being combined into a single pattern without parens around the subordinate patterns.

entry.title: Stop filename match from returning same name twice
entry.content:
commit 953733bae75dbf1a9a360bb49d6ea04a6ac9a167 parent 8d2a746de26da9e4e7c0ba50a405dc3f066681af Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 3 Oct 2018 19:32:01 -0400
Stop filename match from returning same name twice
Users reported that as the filename list grew small, they often would be given the same filename twice. After reproducing the situation by hand, I discovered the filename matcher needed to be careful about not returning the same name twice in a row.

entry.title: Merge pull request #172 from dropbox/more-nonces
entry.content:
commit 998f4dfccd71ab41658b1972c1bd1ade5df0fa55 parent 81fda1ca999e58b48ace7cba30050fd1fb088970 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 27 Jun 2018 09:36:11 -0700
Merge pull request #172 from dropbox/more-nonces
Fix nonces by adding them to all script, link tags

entry.title: Fix nonces by adding them to all script, link tags
entry.content:
commit 6e56bbce6b5ec3a989ab2dd459a14fac7ea14fdc parent 81fda1ca999e58b48ace7cba30050fd1fb088970 Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Tue 26 Jun 2018 11:46:43 -0400
Fix nonces by adding them to all script, link tags
It turns out? Our CSP wants nonces on *every* script and link tag, not just inline scripts. Thanks to the recent template simplification, its now easy to use the Nonce both up in the main layout.html template and also down in specific templates like fileview.html.
This also simplifies the code by precomputing the full text of the HTML attribute, so that the templates neednt be festooned with if statements.

entry.title: Merge pull request #171 from dropbox/try-templates
entry.content:
commit 81fda1ca999e58b48ace7cba30050fd1fb088970 parent 23328c528924aed917c4ebac327d11eb26418854 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Tue 19 Jun 2018 19:18:15 -0700
Merge pull request #171 from dropbox/try-templates
Make template relationships explicit in their text

entry.title: Make template relationships explicit in their text
entry.content:
commit de47f0266c513ea56a690cca296ecc74d55b3c23 parent 23328c528924aed917c4ebac327d11eb26418854 Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 13 Jun 2018 23:34:46 +0000
Make template relationships explicit in their text
Instead of composing templates by first rendering the page template to a string and then inserting it into the layout template, lets load real Go template stacks so that the relationship is explicit inside each page template, and so that only a single rendering run is necessary.
By letting all templates render in the same data context, this will open the way to CSP noncing of `<script>` tags whether theyre in the layout or whether they live down in a page template.

entry.title: Fix Markdown code snippets piled at top of page
entry.content:
commit 41e908ee4c561257f8790abf81f367dbcdaa9e9f parent 43476134b627cc1083b8f7c8e60f0980d54c4c4c Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 24 May 2018 06:12:04 -0400
Fix Markdown code snippets piled at top of page
A very generic CSS class name (code) was used in the file viewer to position the pane of source code absolutely at the top of the page. Alas, code is also used as a CSS class when prism.js is highlighting a code snippet inside of Markdown. So lets fix the collision.

entry.title: Search in repo when initiated from a file view (#6)
entry.content:
commit 1527d56c3b667b265954536fe40b7b6146686822 parent a26d086add16f9c1ad694490c661aec7e85cda57 Author: Samer Masterson <nosefrog@gmail.com> Date: Wed 14 Feb 2018 16:00:25 -0800
Search in repo when initiated from a file view (#6)
When a user highlights a search term in the file viewer and presses `/` to search, we currently forget what repositories they were searching earlier and widen back out to a search of all repositories. Until we can do something more sophisticated, lets at least restrict the search they create with `/` to the repository of the file theyre viewing.

entry.title: Don't pushState on initial navigation (#7)
entry.content:
commit 8d7dd8e8eaa9ed03831310d410703184cc2fb7ac parent a26d086add16f9c1ad694490c661aec7e85cda57 Author: Samer Masterson <nosefrog@gmail.com> Date: Wed 14 Feb 2018 16:13:58 -0800
Don't pushState on initial navigation (#7)
When the user arrives at `/search/?q=` they are usually redirected immediately to a more detailed URL, which shouldnt get its own entry in the browser history or else they will have to press Back twice to see the page they were on before being sent to Livegrep.

entry.title: If a tag index is provided, search it first
entry.content:
commit dace8f1bf30a27db9e95f582e845bab0c4914aff parent e0017e5ca345fe5354186ca30c08d7d302db783e Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 5 Oct 2017 18:02:26 +0000
If a tag index is provided, search it first
On the assumption that tagged lines have greater semantic weight than other lines that match the users search, lets power a search by consulting the tags index first then falling back to the main index.

entry.title: Free tags code_searcher before creating a new one
entry.content:
commit 133a7fd39ab1b5181c5499393b4c62fee38dbf2b parent c9ab573611f835e5f5ad708a6135fbf6cf3c96f3 Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 17 Jan 2018 17:11:27 -0500
Free tags code_searcher before creating a new one
Otherwise, a server run with `-load_tags` will leak a memory map to its tags index every time it reloads, potentially keeping old index files alive instead of letting the filesystem remove them.

entry.title: Add buttons to narrow results by file extensions
entry.content:
commit 1705f305c15cab76fdc2b56e53e9de56989195ea parent b4437d5e845014013936392ff24f800f76492a9c Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Sun 10 Dec 2017 21:28:09 -0500
Add buttons to narrow results by file extensions
A popular request from users: buttons that automatically narrow the current search to files matching a single extension. The extensions offered are all culled from the currently displayed files.
Because these buttons need to advance the search history URL to a new state from which the user often wants to return by hitting Back, this diff also fixes livegrep's previous problem of not preserving browser URL history; we now create a browser history state for each search that successfully returns and is drawn on the screen.

entry.title: Bugfix: without a tags index, build no searcher
entry.content:
commit 452ecad265034dbe80d378582024051fe567df2c parent 9a539114f771f24e90c15c8c7e37436d576ebc11 Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 8 Nov 2017 11:00:50 -0500
Bugfix: without a tags index, build no searcher
Several conditionals in `grpc_server.cc` expect the tags `code_searcher` pointer to be NULL if no tag index has been provided:
``` if (tagdata != nullptr) response->set_has_tags(tagdata_ != nullptr); if (tagdata_ == NULL) ```
But, alas, the initialization routine always creates a tags searcher. Even worse, it leaves it un-finalized if no tags index was provided. Among other things, this crashes codesearch if `tags:...` is specified but no tags index has been provided. And with the debut of our new tags-first search logic, it also makes the service crash for normal searches (!) if no tags index is available. So here we pivot to the behavior the server code expects: a NULL pointer if no tags index is loaded.

entry.title: Store prefs in a long-lived cookie
entry.content:
commit 89725ee0be38bea2385270d8bbcc14c51c899bb3 parent b769fe6d571e06b48a8c4e3a1a665569db45537d Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Mon 9 Oct 2017 19:15:28 +0000
Store prefs in a long-lived cookie
If we don't provide an expiration, this sets a session cookie. But we'd like preferences to be more persistant than that. js-cookie interprets the `expires` argument as days until expiry; 100 years should be plenty.

entry.title: Stop tag file regular expressions from eating tabs
entry.content:
commit f52850932d5550d8c313ebd1e133fff47451f6cf parent e3aad6b262b4889430bb902349712ca8e42c766a Author: Brandon Rhodes <brhodes@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 4 Oct 2017 22:48:38 +0000
Stop tag file regular expressions from eating tabs
Since the identifier field and filename field in a tags file cannot contain tabs, our regular expressions that match those fields should avoid trying to eat tabs. The actual chance of a mismatch is small, but this tiny bit of extra correctness should also give the patterns the best possible chance of running quickly.

entry.title: Use newer rules_node to support builds behind an HTTP proxy
entry.content:
commit d268aa1161264ce720d11c056b0977daa303669b parent 073f3e5f318906f2c4140f219f3460352ccf537e Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Mon 18 Sep 2017 20:43:48 +0000

entry.title: Skip chunks that don't contain desired repos
entry.content:
commit 1e4efb87791232d1b8a739627a9420bce007e12a parent 073f3e5f318906f2c4140f219f3460352ccf537e Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Fri 15 Sep 2017 23:59:04 +0000
Skip chunks that don't contain desired repos
When indexing, codesearch builds chunks in the order that repositories are listed in the configuration. When searching, it examines chunks in the same order. This means that it finds results from repos in roughly the order repos listed in the configuration (modulo multiple threads concurrently processing chunks).
Since repo_pat constraints are applied after the main suffix array search, this means that the search may examine and discard many candidate lines before it ever reaches the desired repo, which can take a long time. On our instance (17 repos, ~11GB index), restricting a search like "e" to the last repo takes 6-7x as long as the same search restricted to the first repo.
This change allows us to skip irrelevant chunks entirely. However, the improvement in overall search performance is limited by the unchunked filename search happening in parallel: even though the main search completes more quickly, the RPC must still wait for the filename search before returning results, so there's potential for further improvement here.

entry.content:
commit e38ceaf3ec323c40c6fed17daae42183d172d2e4 parent c8b8b9ae7fefb277855f8687a34eb99660e2132a Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 13 Sep 2017 20:56:52 +0000
Load highlight.js & theme from cdnjs
This was a major contributor to bundle size, since the bundle pulled in all languages supported by highlight.js. The version hosted on cdnjs only supports a large handful of popular languages; we can add support for additional languages on a one-off basis if we desire.

entry.title: Make -docroot default to web/ in bazel-built runfiles
entry.content:
commit c8b8b9ae7fefb277855f8687a34eb99660e2132a parent 6c1baa95392dfdc92358f5b6d3e073fc00e91675 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Tue 12 Sep 2017 01:30:11 +0000

entry.title: Use dropbox/rules_node to build JS packages
entry.content:
commit 6c1baa95392dfdc92358f5b6d3e073fc00e91675 parent 9be52d4e74e9b1cc9eed5bb79cc5b1914e4001d4 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Fri 1 Sep 2017 18:07:21 +0000
Use dropbox/rules_node to build JS packages
- Load jquery, backbone, and underscore from cdnjs instead of hosting locally (and removes them from the local repo) - Use webpack (via bazel) to build a JS bundle for each page
This removes all vendored third-party js libraries (except for html.js; I couldn't find that in NPM, and anyway it's not that big).
JS source is organized under web/src/, and the road is paved to refactor it into files/modules.
The major drawback is that now `livegrep` must be run with -docroot set to a bazel-built location (I've been passing `-docroot bazel-bin/cmd/livegrep/livegrep.runfiles/com_github_livegrep_livegrep/web/`), and JS changes require a rebuild (`bazel build //web:webpack_build` is usually good enough).

entry.title: From file view, "enter" opens search in new tab
entry.content:
commit 47b6096d42e654328cd5bf756af4033276fd7b89 parent f47929c9cb917a91a983741e62eae2405dac14fc Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 6 Sep 2017 01:29:47 +0000
From file view, "enter" opens search in new tab
This is meant to smooth the flow where a user wants to trace multiple layers of a call stack, and then switch back and forth between inspecting the function bodies.
The change will be a bit disruptive for users accustomed to "enter" performing a search in the current tab; hopefully it shouldn't be too hard for them to switch to "/".

entry.title: Tweak max_matches behaviour
entry.content:
commit df44a1028023939a4de5a8f8296427e3adf7c50c parent 1d33ef816ba65f7b813bffa15a6d868a7400d468 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017 03:25:35 +0000
Tweak max_matches behaviour
- If `max_matches:` is provided in the query, use that as the limit, regardless of a limit passed on the `codesearch` command line. This is on the theory that, if the user provides a `max_matches` value greater than the configured limit, it's because they want to see more results. If they want to see a LOT of results and are willing to wait for it, that's their choice. - Any time the search completes early (without an exhaustive list of results), indicate that the count in the UI is not exact. Included in this change because we're making it easier to hit the time limit (rather than the match limit). - Mention `max_matches:` in the help section.

entry.title: Minor css change to allow users to highlight the file path more easily.
entry.content:
commit ee553a61edccabdf27e4b541c17ee2593e3c3298 parent ba23b0610f9c51bfde881bca723b3482f4df3388 Author: Ted Wang <tpc.wang@gmail.com> Date: Thu 20 Jul 2017 20:19:58 -0500
Minor css change to allow users to highlight the file path more easily.
Currently, the <a> tag takes up the entire length of the header div. This means that you can't highlight the file path if you click down and drag left to highlight the path from the right.
This change makes the <a> tag take up only the minimum width needed, allowing highlighting to work as expected. The background color change is done to merge the two backgrounds and produce the same color as before.

Add explanatory comments to object & struct fields
Some of these are reasonably obvious, but some are a bit subtle. I thought it would be helpful to record the understanding I've extracted from the code (and be corrected if my understanding is wrong!).
It seemed particularly useful to note the effective lifetimes of the things which are only used during index construction. (It might further be useful to factor those out into separate builder classes of some sort.)

entry.title: Fix calculation of ASCII character classes.
entry.content:
commit 0790b513beabd5b4d44d833aa6b1f31b65192db3 parent 1300e87134e4f510751530aa0c3d2f834f5a5c98 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 24 Jun 2017 10:13:23 -0700
Fix calculation of ASCII character classes.
In practice, this would only fail if a class contained a range that crossed the ASCII boundary (< 0x80), and was smaller than kMaxWidth; Because all 32 codepoints following 0x7f are useless control characters, such ranges have no purpose in practice and so this bug was ~impossible to observe.

entry.title: Add repository browser
entry.content:
commit 6b1b3f61efeb3b99f218f0d807651a5b8d2ab7e6 parent 277d7f2609a814aa1f7a839ef059f63447e59815 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Thu 25 May 2017 06:28:00 +0000
Add repository browser
This adds the ability to view source files directly in livegrep, as an alternative to linking to external viewers configured by `url-pattern`. This is desirable for a couple of reasons:
- It's a common pattern to search for something in the codebase, find it, examine its surroundings, and search again for something nearby (for example, when following a chain of function calls).
- The external viewer might be slow (for example, if it's Phabricator), and it's valuable to get a snappy response when clicking through to view a search result.
The file browser is implemented as part of `livegrep`, and requires having git repositories available to the `livegrep` process. Therefore, `livegrep` now accepts an additional config file (in the same format used by `codesearch`) specifying where to find repos on disk. If this config is not provided, we retain the old behaviour where clicking through to view a search result goes directly to the external site.

entry.title: Add Reload RPC to reinitialize codesearch backend
entry.content:
commit ca728c7c05a662289f0f0d50c0e64b09e3a3c54c parent 0683e6e6118873cd5416b2f18a2a366d50b91806 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Wed 31 May 2017 08:52:30 +0000
Add Reload RPC to reinitialize codesearch backend
This shuts down the grpc server and starts everything up again. Intended to be called after a new index has been created on disk, to begin serving from it.
To avoid leaking memory on every reload, this change also releases allocated memory where necessary. `valgrind --tool=memcheck --leak-check=full` reported no leaks or errors during some cursory searches and reloads.

entry.title: Use css content: to uncopiably show line numbers
entry.content:
commit 04620802378b5832cd3fe3abba869fb52d7dfbea parent 63235683a5df30e8f194a194bc14b51231698604 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Fri 26 May 2017 01:36:18 +0000
Use css content: to uncopiably show line numbers
With this approach, line numbers are not included when code is selected and copied, in at least Chrome and Firefox.
I used the `aria-label` attribute to hold the line number so that the link is described in a way accessible to screen readers, though I'm not sure this is the best solution.

entry.title: Add livegrep-fetch-reindex helper command
entry.content:
commit ad4b81cc12a3d90fd3f37ea0aaa09797b5031136 parent 8b490a26bd4c66647f537b2796b793618a14d209 Author: Josiah Boning <josiah@dropbox.com> Date: Tue 23 May 2017 23:52:45 +0000
Add livegrep-fetch-reindex helper command
Inspired by `livegrep-github-reindex`, this clones/fetches a number of git repositories in parallel and then regenerates the index. Repository information is provided in the index json config format used by `codesearch`, with a `remote` field in the `metadata` dictionary indicating where to fetch the repository from.
The code is almost entirely plagiarized from `livegrep-github-reindex`. `livegrep-github-index` itself could probably be refactored to generate an index config with `remote` fields and then invoke this.

entry.title: indexer: check whether ref resolved to commit
entry.content:
commit 6b7edc9d23d3fe93ae0cd94e305be875441703fb parent 457fd83d5eb68469693a7512edb304762897adaa Author: bnewbold <bnewbold@robocracy.org> Date: Mon 15 May 2017 22:02:49 -0700
indexer: check whether ref resolved to commit
If a reference can't be resolved to a commit, libgit2's git_revparse_single() will return a non-zero status. This patch adds a check for this status and prints to stderr if this happens.
Previously codesearch would just crash with a null object assertion, if, for example, run against an empty repository with no branches or commits.

livegrep-github-reindex: support GitHub enterprise

entry.title: livegrep-github-reindex: support GitHub enterprise
entry.content:
commit 8d4bb2ff3ee8cd269155aa84b8b54ee5085be773 parent 5ae320758df37c8511d0f3867418bf1762494d74 Author: Drew Fisher <drew.m.fisher@gmail.com> Date: Thu 16 Mar 2017 16:21:03 -0700
livegrep-github-reindex: support GitHub enterprise
GitHub Enterprise interactions work essentially the same as those with the GitHub public API, but with a different API base URL. Happily, `go-github` already supports this; we just need a flag to allow users to point the indexer at their GitHub Enterprise base URL.

entry.title: github index: allow indexing a specific revision
entry.content:
commit f7819bddea936f152f697f5894e1a2924034b61a parent 21e93ce462889ca9c8cb4c4de3ab25675032990a Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Tue 29 Dec 2015 14:15:20 -0800
github index: allow indexing a specific revision
And allow controlling whether or not we --revparse.
This is most useful for a single repository, but might also be useful for something like Android that has many repos with a shared branching scheme.

entry.title: CaseFoldLiteral: Handle all ASCII characters.
entry.content:
commit 577cdfff8e801875684b40c9767fe459421fb127 parent 8f0b63e57be9b9db377776d8e70fbc063c2289f8 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 22 May 2015 21:15:35 -0700
CaseFoldLiteral: Handle all ASCII characters.
If we see a non-alphabetic ASCII character, we know it matches when casefolded only with itself.

entry.title: CaseFoldLiteral: Use the general Concat()
entry.content:
commit 8f0b63e57be9b9db377776d8e70fbc063c2289f8 parent 985db2f0baee7833b438585d445ac2adc0bda9ac Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 22 May 2015 21:13:40 -0700
CaseFoldLiteral: Use the general Concat()
Because casefolded runes yield nontrivial index keys (including Any()), we need to do the full concat routine to find the correct pieces to keep, rather than concatenating everything pairwise.

entry.title: Drop the inorder traversal when searching a chunk.
entry.content:
commit d174167c33f694d8b06c886bcf0b08833b6369ed parent 7c4f996a9a953c9ce87dea77a92435f2ff445dc4 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 7 Feb 2015 12:27:02 -0800
Drop the inorder traversal when searching a chunk.
I wanted it to make testing easier, but I've got a better test harness now, and it was unnecessary complexity. Keep the explicit stack instead of recursion, so I don't have to define a helper function, and in case I decide this should be BFS for some reason.

entry.title: Fix permalinks when backends contain non-word characters.
entry.content:
commit 419f3a24dd13c50973c4cbc0d2dc20368f56c292 parent 1e2761438467c1043c9ddcaf025cfd3db9c5fc0d Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com> Date: Wed 31 Dec 2014 17:46:55 -0800
Fix permalinks when backends contain non-word characters.
I used "v1.2.3" and "z_foo" in my backend names, which confused the permalink code. I've loosened the regular expression to accept anything except slashes.
(Alternatively, I could have added assertions to fail backends serving with such names, but I haven't done that, nor have I made an assertion that slashes aren't allowed, but they clearly aren't.)

entry.title: Redo search when backend changes.
entry.content:
commit 1e2761438467c1043c9ddcaf025cfd3db9c5fc0d parent eeb283a6f026c04418775af9433f81db4589e647 Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com> Date: Wed 31 Dec 2014 17:27:40 -0800
Redo search when backend changes.
The comparison of whether the current search has changed failed to take into account the backend. I've fixed that by doing the search when the backends are not equal.

entry.title: Handle "other" githubs; fix github links.
entry.content:
commit eeb283a6f026c04418775af9433f81db4589e647 parent c968041688f2a40bdb2a46de44043001c8d59c59 Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com> Date: Wed 31 Dec 2014 17:12:36 -0800
Handle "other" githubs; fix github links.
With this commit, a user specifying a valid URL for their github index metadata will link directly to it, rather than to github.com. This is useful for organizations that run Github Enterprise / Github FI on-premise.
As far as I could tell, Github linking only worked for the first backend, because the server never sent back the backend as part of a query response. I've fixed this quickly, by looking up the backend in the in_flight query. I'm not certain that this is correct.
I've also extended shorten(ref) to shorten "origin/master" to "master." It's hard to make all possible git references work when plugged into the github URL namespace, but this one is common enough that it makes sense. (And if you named a branch origin/master, you're already in plenty of pain.) I could have made it more explicit by requiring the configuration to specify refs/remotes/origin/master, but that seemed too irksome.

entry.title: Allow HTML template customization via server configuration.
entry.content:
commit c968041688f2a40bdb2a46de44043001c8d59c59 parent 0a9fc9e7c893af5cb1386406bb5ed0986d0fd354 Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com> Date: Wed 31 Dec 2014 16:07:01 -0800
Allow HTML template customization via server configuration.
This commit lets the user inject HTML into the layout.html template to customize the page. The intent is to be able to add additional links or to otherwise monkey-patch the UI in a lightweight way via the config file.
The template engine (http://golang.org/pkg/html/template/) is clever and parses the HTML to escape its inputs, and assumes the inputs are untrusted. In this case, it's fair to say that the server configuration is trusted (and intended to be passed through), which is why the type in config.go is "template.HTML".

Re-ordering path matching, to prefer path with backend specified.

entry.title: Re-ordering path matching, to prefer path with backend specified.
entry.content:
commit c9f05de3a27ef34c2d0f553d27c4c52795876025 parent 6783e9b3b944fb43e6882fbd978415ab95f922f3 Author: Philip Zeyliger <philip@cloudera.com> Date: Wed 17 Dec 2014 20:43:22 -0800
Re-ordering path matching, to prefer path with backend specified.
The backend that I was choosing wasn't being respected. After confirming (with bin/dump_file) that the backend should have had the right data (and killing the relevant backend and not seeing any change) and adding some logging, I realized that the :backend parameter wasn't being passed along into api.go.
Based on my reading of pat/mux.go, specifically:
if ph.pat != "/" && len(ph.pat) > 0 && ph.pat[len(ph.pat)-1] == '/' { return p, true
It seems that any pattern that ends with a slash can match even if there's random stuff after it. And, yes, the Add() calls are ordered.
I've tested the /api call manually. The /search path seems to have the same issue, so I changed that too.

entry.title: Enforce a (configurable) max-line-length limit.
entry.content:
commit 5a77733d75cfd666895545e3b23cfe8498d68f0a parent 3cf7797b176cdbc401029a525e732d5b79ca8488 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 16 May 2014 10:56:52 -0700
Enforce a (configurable) max-line-length limit.
Lines over a certain length are almost certainly machine-generated or otherwise uninteresting, and we shouldn't clutter the index or search results with them.

entry.title: Add option to search filesystem paths as well as git.
entry.content:
commit 5244b689a042bf8b1d78ac6f51cc418a874953e5 parent c7dcc829ce0919c36a26fa4a14b12030c704c4f4 Author: Christian Ternus <ternus@cternus.net> Date: Thu 24 Apr 2014 16:57:21 -0400
Add option to search filesystem paths as well as git.
This patch also updates both the CLI and JSON interfaces to support filesystem scans.
Work still to be done: rework API/interface to be more informative about filesystem paths. Right now it's using a dummy repo which causes extraneous info to show up in results.

Among other things, this lets use json.Encoder and Decoder directly, for less copying and no arbitrary line-length limits.

entry.title: Use mmap-backed content chunks on index creation.
entry.content:
commit 11286e6e2a1ce5ddb7ff77d1b335482f7d750b7d parent 9f5568346739347e114b13a9b91b3a752b5f0741 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 23 Dec 2012 22:13:20 -0500
Use mmap-backed content chunks on index creation.
Store content data in multiple chunks, and allocate using mmap as we go. Build contents per-file into a temporary buffer, and then convert to in-memory format.

entry.title: Remove the `lengths' cache from radix_sorter.
entry.content:
commit f81d2f5775a698ed48ca8162b68268bb88950b01 parent 11d8a9af09c53462c60d88ba0b5d412e7372e4df Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 15 Jul 2012 15:01:45 -0400
Remove the `lengths' cache from radix_sorter.
This is unnecessary:- For indexing, we don't need it, since the radix sort automatically stops sorting once it runs off the end of a a string, and for comparison, we are doing a O(n) scan anyways, so the data is in cache and adding a memchr() (empirically) does not have a measurable slowdown.
And since we did one such allocation per thread, this dramatically improves memory usage when indexing, especially as we bump the chunk size.

entry.content:
commit 026f39a03301f781c4a59c164d824a7312199c4d parent 8e8ff690d08699395a607e4548f343408b87a8e2 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 23 Jun 2012 16:24:16 -0700
Refactor kChunkSize into a member of chunk_allocator.
We can still set it as before, but now already-constructed objects track it internally, and can pick it up from an index file.

entry.title: Make chunk_allocator::chunks_ a vector<>
entry.content:
commit 785f0406a880f33a4ecb711935accb49af56bf5b parent 00e5c25260d5b4fc596c6e29a0207e51a76715d2 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 22 Jun 2012 11:32:58 -0700
Make chunk_allocator::chunks_ a vector<>
This will save some logic in dump_load, and we don't actually any of the operations a linked-list makes fast.

entry.title: Refactor the whole chunk_allocator mess.
entry.content:
commit 00e5c25260d5b4fc596c6e29a0207e51a76715d2 parent 280445156c4020965ea6dadc9098f1835f1d1276 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 16 Jun 2012 16:56:58 -0400
Refactor the whole chunk_allocator mess.
You now have to hand a code_searcher a chunk_allocator after creation, and dump, load, and in-memory all get their own chunk_allocator subclasses.
chunk_allocator itself is now pure-virtual; A mem_allocator subclass allocates chunk using new[].
chunk_allocator gains a free_chunk method, allowing us to properly free chunks.

entry.title: When indexing, also mmap chunks out of the on-disk index file.
entry.content:
commit 48b60d8231ae211db706efebac3b37b340822390 parent 87c7ba81005bec1dad21e9c7ebbc79058e2df296 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 2 Jun 2012 19:13:45 -0400

entry.title: Always dump the full kChunkSize of data for chunks.
entry.content:
commit 87c7ba81005bec1dad21e9c7ebbc79058e2df296 parent be409a8df39067461da55d866bcdf5092c363be2 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 2 Jun 2012 18:52:17 -0400
Always dump the full kChunkSize of data for chunks.
Previously, we dumped chunk->size, rounded up to a page boundary. Just dumping the entire kChunkSize makes things more consistent and simpler.
While we're at it, fix the definition of alignp() and aligng() to actually be correct. Oops.

entry.content:
commit be409a8df39067461da55d866bcdf5092c363be2 parent 852ae8f5a1519ad355c1bd27373163fdad13b5f1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 2 Jun 2012 15:55:24 -0400
Move the chunk_map into chunk_allocator.
This makes much more conceptual sense, and will make even more once the chunk_allocator becomes the ultimate owner of ->data.

entry.title: Don't feed RE2 more than a meg of text at a time.
entry.content:
commit 078e2a4cb97c96b871b03393cf1f5eccfeeb029f parent 23ff5e476e2a6b060f50cad4efd7a48895f12166 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 20 May 2012 18:12:44 -0400
Don't feed RE2 more than a meg of text at a time.
Unfortunately, there are some really degenerate regexes that will take over a minute just to search a single chunk, during which we don't get to check our timeout. To protect against such attacks, don't scan more than a megabyte of text at once between checking the timeout condition.

entry.title: Maintain an explicit text -> chunk map.
entry.content:
commit 23ff5e476e2a6b060f50cad4efd7a48895f12166 parent 72e6f351c579c5f4bd8aa8f6c0ba2b06bfd32a8b Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 9 May 2012 09:40:15 -0400
Maintain an explicit text -> chunk map.
Stop doing the silly game where we force chunks to be aligned on some ridiculous boundary. We don't even ever need to do that lookup on a hot path.

entry.title: Improve handling of queries that are very sparse in file matches.
entry.content:
commit a8813d2ef46510955190a62882692b6ef6c5dc9b parent 301d7131b872867062277a50f8524f88ce38eda1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 30 Mar 2012 19:52:11 -0400
Improve handling of queries that are very sparse in file matches.
If the file match is sparse enough, and the regex index key is dense enough, it makes sense to just do a full scan of all matching text, rather than scanning using the index results, which will include lots of spurious hits.

Build and use an interval tree (augmented BST) for chunk_file lookup.

entry.title: Merge chunk_files spanning identical ranges.
entry.content:
commit 950972f755324fd8721314bb9ae20a8cd73e4830 parent 030f7325d87f8843acda186923d4805f64068a50 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 4 Mar 2012 17:24:13 -0500
Merge chunk_files spanning identical ranges.
This is a slightly speedup to find_match, but will be important when we replace the linear search with an interval tree.

entry.title: Sort all the chunk_file lists synchronously at the end.
entry.content:
commit 030f7325d87f8843acda186923d4805f64068a50 parent b33817a2356b092991706ab6953df3735b4190d1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Tue 6 Mar 2012 09:22:50 -0500
Sort all the chunk_file lists synchronously at the end.
It's not safe to sort the chunk_file list just because we're done with that chunk, because we're going to add more elements to it, later, as we go.

entry.title: lsd_radix_sort: Reduce passes over the buffer.
entry.content:
commit d37909711b902a467def54ec51f5649392ed6545 parent fb29d9220302cc28e993d5b9a34819d9fbfcc30a Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Tue 28 Feb 2012 09:36:28 -0500
lsd_radix_sort: Reduce passes over the buffer.
Compute all four counts in a single pass. This is noticeably faster on at least one test case.

entry.title: radix-sort.cc: Also use a per-thread scratch area.
entry.content:
commit fb29d9220302cc28e993d5b9a34819d9fbfcc30a parent e974ac25f16c9964ee011b487c7c3a6f0e7a330c Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 26 Feb 2012 18:20:54 -0500
radix-sort.cc: Also use a per-thread scratch area.

entry.title: indexes[] only really needs to be kChunkSize / kMinFilterRatio large.
entry.content:
commit e974ac25f16c9964ee011b487c7c3a6f0e7a330c parent 1143a246e577140b43ac281020ab2976ff7b74c9 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 26 Feb 2012 10:07:58 -0500
indexes[] only really needs to be kChunkSize / kMinFilterRatio large.
If we're ever populating it past that point, we're wasting work, anyways.

entry.title: Use thread-local data for the indexes[] array, instad of per-call.
entry.content:
commit 1143a246e577140b43ac281020ab2976ff7b74c9 parent e9ea5ba13313348d0226a9b77917fcb27b70ae42 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 25 Feb 2012 21:48:35 -0500
Use thread-local data for the indexes[] array, instad of per-call.
Calling new[] on that much memory all the time seems to result in a high incidence of getting unmapped anonymous memory, which then has to be faulted in a page at a time, which is slow.

entry.title: stress.js: Only show global stats.
entry.content:
commit e9ea5ba13313348d0226a9b77917fcb27b70ae42 parent 481a1667756e0d57f6c8c30af68da6851835cbf1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 25 Feb 2012 20:22:34 -0500
stress.js: Only show global stats.
per-thread stats aren't really interesting, anyways. Unless they are vastly different for some reason, but I'm not interested in that now, and it should be unlikely.

entry.title: bench.js: Warn if search IDs move backwards.
entry.content:
commit 78dd2a96ce0d2e331979028ce1d79a81bb957e9e parent e2570f8589fdd7e1fa88cf6f343cad252d19f924 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 22 Jan 2012 16:15:00 -0500
bench.js: Warn if search IDs move backwards.
At the moment, this indicates a server bug, where the server was dispatching multiple searches at once. This may not remain true forever, but is worth noting for now.

entry.title: Actually only allow one in-flight search per client.
entry.content:
commit e2570f8589fdd7e1fa88cf6f343cad252d19f924 parent 550c65bf59f00e97378aa3aa6ee9bd5ac550695e Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 22 Jan 2012 16:00:13 -0500
Actually only allow one in-flight search per client.
I guess this used to get enforced at the backend side, but when I moved to multiple backends, I forget to enforce it in the frontend. So I think we were basically always saturating the backend, even if there was no reason to.

entry.title: kludge: double-JSON encode messages sent over dnode.
entry.content:
commit e5086179f682c60d6c53193900007e12b4b62fbc parent abc3c83204db60fc71e7574e2e595f3d4e800b8d Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Mon 16 Jan 2012 16:18:27 -0500
kludge: double-JSON encode messages sent over dnode.
This speeds things up by at least 2x by preventing dnode from having to walk all of our lists of matches serializing them, when we know a priori that there are no functions or cycles to worry about.

entry.title: An alternation can never anchor on the right.
entry.content:
commit 1152ece8af11369a9a73da56e220692bd92fb65f parent bb3f7d54668940eb5077c8e155153bbe904b0179 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 11 Jan 2012 09:40:57 -0500
An alternation can never anchor on the right.
It's just too hairy to keep track of the tails, as well as when we bailed out early and so don't have complete information. The incorrect tail-tracking should mean we never actually managed to make a useful concatenation, anyways.

entry.title: search_thread: Tie the lifetime of the thread_pool to search_thread.
entry.content:
commit a108e8570fa5f0debe3160ec74ef2e88b67502eb parent 3ecef4cb9aeb573aceaf840e1ecc8b94f80ffab8 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 8 Jan 2012 11:19:05 -0500
search_thread: Tie the lifetime of the thread_pool to search_thread.
Now that we have the separate search_thread class, there's no need to manually manage the lifetime of the pool; We can just tie it to the search_threaad.

entry.title: There's no need for the search_functor class.
entry.content:
commit 3ecef4cb9aeb573aceaf840e1ecc8b94f80ffab8 parent 10b30d55ec45d152e4d19b55d349e3554556405b Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 8 Jan 2012 11:17:04 -0500
There's no need for the search_functor class.
A normal function works just as well, and we can even make it a static member inside search_thread.

entry.title: Optimize the index-loading process.
entry.content:
commit dcbe2cc95f2d5c3509613fd9ec0a3874a9be51f8 parent 9e5cc8802fc106edc0bca8951ee055d6c42e1afc Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Thu 8 Dec 2011 00:34:44 -0500
Optimize the index-loading process.
- When reading a large number of small pieces of data, call istream::read() once into a temporary buffer and parse that, rather than making O(n) calls -- read() is really slow. - Rather than using vector::push_back, resize the vector once and overwrite elements in place.

entry.title: Indexer: Improve support for repetition constructs.
entry.content:
commit 031c5211e82dabc1d9eb26536c0ae985e645dc1b parent 012ce939b138e9ef657ad6729fbbf38dffcda0d9 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sat 3 Dec 2011 12:03:09 -0500
Indexer: Improve support for repetition constructs.
Add a special anchor flag that indicates that the anchor is repetition. This flag is only meaningful if kAnchorBoth is set, in which case it indicates that the index can anchor at *either* the left-hand-side *or* the right-hand-side, but that commiting to one anchor (specifically, in Concat) destroys its ability to anchor at the other side.
This flag can be provided to repetition constructs (i.e. + or {N}), increasing the chance that we'll be able to attach them to an adjacent index term.

entry.title: Stop reading objects from git.
entry.content:
commit cbe2bc228087af4f0dc5bae837e9d77fa6457b8b parent e3a1677e4172f098543ed3a463230137f6726c69 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 27 Nov 2011 13:11:25 -0500
Stop reading objects from git.
Instead, store object contents as a vector of StringPiece's referencing the chunk data we already have.
This avoids ever having to go to disk, greatly speeding up the process of checking the validity of proposed matches and retrieving context.
Still TODO: Update the serialization format.

entry.title: No, really, don't use websockets.
entry.content:

entry.title: Adaptively allow shorter filters if necessary.
entry.content:
commit 3ddf14a400e8cb7763cf39806306fc9a1762b6eb parent 07186afa129949952d8489d9d26318c9589ad1af Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 13 Nov 2011 17:01:12 -0500
Adaptively allow shorter filters if necessary.
With the previous optimization, we can even productively use a single-letter filter in many cases. Some more testing is probably necessary to determine when the overhead of a single-letter filter is too high.

entry.title: Rework index search to reduce the number of calls into re2.
entry.content:
commit 07186afa129949952d8489d9d26318c9589ad1af parent 61f69aa256d0c217bff1b668b9cc790dcb9c6589 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 13 Nov 2011 16:52:27 -0500
Rework index search to reduce the number of calls into re2.
re2 has some fixed overhead associated with each call, and we can get better performance out of feeding it large pieces of text at a time. If we're searching for something that is relatively dense in the index, we can get a noticeable boost by passing multiple consecutive lines at once to RE2, instead of feeding it a line at a time.
We also get to avoid many of the find_line calls, which are pretty cheap but can add up.

entry.content:
commit a5b13eca2103753bdf52a35bce97e65b89ff681c parent 4f6697ac09a0e741808ea46763bf46889829ba99 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Fri 4 Nov 2011 12:37:28 -0400

entry.title: Use a separate git_repository per search thread.
entry.content:
commit 4f6697ac09a0e741808ea46763bf46889829ba99 parent eb8b82ea963d2f9350009f041b7681dfed7c56ea Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 30 Oct 2011 15:48:32 -0700
Use a separate git_repository per search thread.
This unfortunately means we don't get to share the object cache between them, but it's still a huge win over serializing all access to the repository. Maybe some day libgit2 will actually be threadsafe and we can have the best of both worlds.

entry.title: Back out approximate match counting code.
entry.content:
commit 7ea9a208e82521ec688fd78ca0b34458211800ab parent 5874a1cbb5a132d85992302cb468cd047a4b5771 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 26 Oct 2011 13:08:52 -0700
Back out approximate match counting code.
The current implementation took far too long on regexes that matched every single line, or nearly so. We'll rethink total-match counting later.

entry.title: Skip over the trailing newline when advancing the match position.
entry.content:
commit 5874a1cbb5a132d85992302cb468cd047a4b5771 parent 14fe1f285cd493d31710fccfe9113cc277024741 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Wed 26 Oct 2011 12:25:31 -0700
Skip over the trailing newline when advancing the match position.
The old code would loop forever if given a regex that had a zero-length match immediately before a newline.
Also, add an assertion to catch any similar bugs in the future.

entry.title: Shrink CHUNK_SIZE.
entry.content:
commit 6173b427af7b5152612b837c510a94f3b283f366 parent 0234b91989d08c768c46817e68318ec104d0a9b1 Author: Nelson Elhage <nelhage@nelhage.com> Date: Sun 16 Oct 2011 22:30:09 -0400
Shrink CHUNK_SIZE.
In the current implementation, the linear list of chunk_files is a liability with larger chunks, since we have to search so many files once we've found the right chunk. The right plan here is probably to improve the chunk_file lookup, but this is an improvement.
